tweet: Today in pulp I'm looking at Tron, a film that pushed the boundaries of early CGI as well as using Disney's more traditional animation and post-production skills. It also nailed the tech-noir look!  https://t.co/Crmdm1IGF8

Jean Giraud (Moebius) was the main costume and set designer for Tron. Backlit animation was used for many effects, so costumes and sets were shot in monochrome with colours added in post-production to create a shimmering futuristic look.  https://t.co/ZRwLKUf2mQ

The look of Tron is influenced by two things: motherboards and vector graphics. Most computer aided design used wireframes as did popular arcade games such as Tank Command. The vector look, especially on a black background, was 80s cool!  https://t.co/alBAWBBa5v

Tron is a film about a computer programmer transported inside  a mainframe computer. He has to compete with the other programs and play a number of life-or-death games in his attempt to escape. It's The Matrix, but with laser frisbee...  https://t.co/uIYe1J8sR0

Information International provided most of the CGI on Tron using a Foonley F-1, a high-speed, 36-bit computer with 512 bytes of memory. That's enough to power a Tron Light Cycle and way more than the Apollo moon lander had!  https://t.co/mxJhOkuyG0
"TRON" is a debugging command in some versions of BASIC and stands for TRaceON. Unsurprisingly the 2010 Tron movie sequel didn't use its complementary command: "TROFF"  https://t.co/JJvS8b2a85

After Tron cinema science fiction had a new aesthetic, based on the idea of the virtual world. It's a template that still stands up today, retro-futuristic and still cool.  Tron - we salute you!  https://t.co/M2LIySAsLQ

The original Tron movie was released in 1982, four years after the success of Disney's earlier sci-fi film The Black Hole. However Tron had been in development since 1976 and was initially pitched as a traditional animated motion picture.  https://t.co/9GhwiJGcLh

Tron is a great film because it's an analogue rendering of a digital future. Disney took a risk and put its best minds to it, took the concept seriously and built an immersive sense of a future world that really sticks in the mind.  https://t.co/Rg5PdfVbn9
Sometimes I be wanting to say, "Fuck the world!"  https://t.co/VziFi70Cjk

Postscript: if you get a chance, do stream the Tron soundtrack, composed by Wendy Carlos. It's genuinely great!  https://t.co/amvnVG3YyK
The Tron cast included Jeff Bridges, Bruce Boxleitner, Cindy Morgan and a scene-stealing performance (I think) from David Warner as the villainous Sark.  https://t.co/G7MAO2SDW5

Director Steven Lisberger and Bonnie MacBird  wrote the Tron script, and after discussion with Disney they decided to use live-action elements with both backlit and computer animation into the movie.  https://t.co/Jvb6219E24

For a while it looked like Tron's legacy would be Glen A Larson's short-lived Automan TV series. However the visual creativity of the film proved in the end to be it's most memorable asset.  https://t.co/Dr4EzP8DfM

To help share the CGI load of Tron, New York's MAGI company came on board with more computing power and the SynthaVision system: a library of 25 preformed solid CGI shapes. Without MAGI the Light Cycles would have ended up all polygons...  https://t.co/RmC1ZpSUmb

@PulpLibrarian Some of the technology used in Tron is still used today, specifically Perlin noise (i.e. fractal noise) developed by Ken Perlin to speed up rendering for the the cgi in the film.
